contentrichtext.text: "'''You Call Everybody Darlin''''" is a [[popular music|popular]] [[song]]. It was written by [[Sam Martin (composer)|Sam Martin]], [[Ben Trace]], and [[Clem Watts]] and published in [[1946 in music|1946]]. Several versions were recorded that charted in [[1948 in music|1948]] (mostly recorded that year, but at least one possibly in the previous year): by [[Al Trace]] (Clem Watts' real name; the biggest-selling version), [[Bob Vincent]], [["Smilin'" Jack Smith (music)|Jack Smith]], [[The Andrews Sisters]], [[Jerry Wayne]], and [[Jack Lathrop]]. The song was also recorded by [[Art Lund]] that year. The [[Al Trace]] recording was released by [[Regent Records (US)|Regent Records]] as [[Catalog numbering systems for single records|catalog number]] 117. The record first reached the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' charts on June 18, 1948 and lasted 22 weeks on the chart, peaking at #1.<ref name=Whitburn> {{cite book | last = Whitburn | first = Joel | authorlink = Joel Whitburn | title = Top Pop Records 1940-1955 | publisher = Record Research | year = 1973 }} </ref> The [[Bob Vincent]] recording was released by [[Mercury Records]] as catalog number 5155. The record first reached the [[Billboard magazine]] charts on July 23, 1948 and lasted 12 weeks on the chart, peaking at #13.<ref name=Whitburn/> The [["Smilin'" Jack Smith (music)|Jack Smith]] recording was recorded about December 30, 1947 and released by [[Capitol Records]] as catalog number 15155. The record first reached the [[Billboard magazine]] charts on August 13, 1948 and lasted 9 weeks on the chart, peaking at #13.<ref name=Whitburn/> [[The Andrews Sisters]] recording was recorded on July 26, 1948 and released by [[Decca Records]] as catalog number 24490. The flip side was "[[Underneath the Arches (song)|Underneath the Arches]]". The record first reached the [[Billboard magazine]] charts on August 27, 1948 and lasted 9 weeks on the chart, peaking at #16.<ref name=Whitburn/> The [[Jerry Wayne]] recording was recorded on July 7, 1948 and released by [[Columbia Records]] as catalog number 38286. The record first reached the [[Billboard magazine]] charts on September 10, 1948 and lasted 1 week on the chart, at #26.<ref name=Whitburn/> The [[Jack Lathrop]] recording was released by [[RCA Victor Records]] as catalog number 20-3109. The record first reached the [[Billboard magazine]] charts on September 17, 1948 and lasted 2 weeks on the chart, peaking at #27.<ref name=Whitburn/> The [[Art Lund]] version was recorded on July 16, 1948 and released by [[MGM Records]] as catalog number 10258. Country singer Lamar Morris revived the tune as a minor country chart song in 1973. American country music artist [[K. T. Oslin]] covered the song on her 1990 album, ''[[Love in a Small Town]]''. It was the fourth single released from the project and reached #69 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles & Tracks]] chart. ==References== {{reflist}} {{start}} {{succession box | before = "[[Woody Woodpecker#"The Woody Woodpecker Song"|The Woody Woodpecker Song]]" by [[Kay Kyser]] | title = U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Best Sellers in Stores]] [[List of number-one hits (United States)|number-one single]] | years = August 14â€“21, 1948 ([[Al Trace]]) | after = "[[Twelfth Street Rag]]" by [[Pee Wee Hunt]] }} {{end}} [[Category:1948 songs]] [[Category:Number-one singles in the United States]] [[Category:Songs written by Al Trace]] {{1940s-song-stub}}
